channel.description: Post Politics from The Washington Post is the source for political news headlines, in-depth politics coverage and political opinion, plus breaking news on the Obama administration and White House, Congress, the Supreme Court, elections and more.

image.title: Post Politics: Breaking Politics News, Political Analysis & More - The Washington Post

item.title: The Fix: Are you Ready for Warren … G. Harding?
item.description:
In the past week, Ready for Warren, the designated organization for those ready for President (and current Massachusetts Sen.) Elizabeth Warren, is showing signs of readiness. They are ready to gather signatures. They are ready to hire former Obama campaign workers. They are ready to make the hashtag #ReadyforWarren a thing. Other organizations, like MoveOn.org, have also signaled their readiness.

Read full article >>
item.dc:creator: Jaime Fuller
item.ExtractedText:
By Jaime Fuller December 10 at 11:00 AM Follow @j_fuller In the past week, Ready for Warren, the designated organization for those ready for President (and current Massachusetts Sen.) Elizabeth Warren, is showing signs of readiness. They are ready to gather signatures. They are ready to hire former Obama campaign workers. They are ready to make the hashtag #ReadyforWarren a thing. Other organizations, like MoveOn.org, have also signaled their readiness. However, they do not appear ready to acknowledge that they are not the first people in political history to be ready for Warren. Americans in 1920, after all, thought they were ready for Warren ... G. Harding. Source: Evening times-Republican, September 29, 1920 Now he is remembered as one of the worst presidents in history. Think about that. However, Elizabeth Warren's supporters might still be in the clear. It seems that Harding's supporters were mostly limited to boats, which may explain his lack of lasting support (along with the Teapot Dome Scandal , perhaps). Source: The Washington Post; Jan 9, 1921
Source: New York Times; Jan 17, 192
Source: New York Times; Feb 28, 1923
Source: Washington Post, 1922
It might also be unwise to trust anyone who says they are ready for Hillary. There is a not-so-negligible chance that they might be talking about someone else. Getting ready for Hilary Mantel #BathLitfest pic.twitter.com/opGpA4dH07 — Cerith Mathias (@CerithMathias) March 9, 2013
Source: Bad Sandy Anyway, it's worth putting out there. Jaime Fuller reports on national politics for "The Fix" and Post Politics. She worked previously as an associate editor at the American Prospect, a political magazine based in Washington, D.C.
